title: Liquefaction (Hydrolytic) Necrosis from a Hearing Aid Battery in the Ear Canal
chief_complaint: I am having trouble recognizing conversations in most listening situations.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual hearing loss; acute presentation of foreign body 3 months after hearing aid fitting.
problem_summary.course: Hearing loss is stable; foreign body issue is acute.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss; Right ear foreign body.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Reduced benefit from hearing aids; patient denied pain or sensation of obstruction.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Mild-to-moderate handicap in daily life; recent reduction in hearing aid benefit.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To improve speech recognition and restore hearing aid benefit.

history.present_illness: Patient presented for a comprehensive examination reporting inability to recognize conversations.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to severe sensorineural hearing loss, gradually sloping.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Moderate loss in ability to receive speech (SRT). Slight loss in word recognition ability (WRS) using NU-6 lists.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, static compliance, and middle ear pressure (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal contralateral and ipsilateral thresholds at 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN testing revealed a moderate signal-to-noise ratio loss.

tests.name: Self-report scale
tests.key_findings: Hearing Handicap Inventoryâ€“Elderly (HHIE) indicated mild-to-moderate handicap.

history.prior_management: Fitted with bilateral RITE instruments (using #312 batteries) in Jan 2010.

tests.name: Electroacoustic analysis
tests.key_findings: Revealed proper functioning of the hearing instruments.

history.present_illness: Patient reported receiving reduced benefit from her instruments.
history.otologic_history: Patient denied perception of any obstruction.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.key_findings: Debris observed close to TM, appearing as dark cerumen. Upon attempted removal, found to be a solid, hard object firmly adhering to the canal wall. Identified as a #312 hearing aid battery.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral symmetrical mild-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss with good word recognition in quiet but moderate SNR loss. Following a successful fitting, she returned 3 months later with a #312 hearing aid battery lodged in the right ear canal. The battery was firmly adhered to the canal wall, mimicking impacted cerumen, and could not be removed via standard curette.
counseling_points: The object in your right ear is not wax; it is a hearing aid battery.
Because the battery is stuck to the ear canal wall, I cannot safely remove it here.
This is a medical emergency because the battery can leak fluids that damage the ear.
I am referring you to an ear specialist (otologist) immediately for removal.
Do not put any water or drops in your ear, as moisture can cause the battery to leak more.
notes_for_actor: You are an 84-year-old woman with no signs of dementia.
In the final visit, you are completely unaware that a battery is in your ear.
You feel no pain or fullness; you only notice the hearing aid isn't helping as much.
You should appear surprised when told there is a battery in your ear.
You do not recall losing a battery inside your ear.
